publicwhip.spmotion: *S2M-1916# Brian Adam: Cuts in Local Benefits Services—That the Parliament expresses great concern about the impact of the proposed cuts by the Department of Work and Pensions in local provision of benefits advice; regrets the likely reduction in benefits uptake by many vulnerable people; deplores the unfair geographical spread of the cuts, leaving Grampian, Tayside and Fife without any local offices; recognises the consequential increased workload that will fall on local authority and voluntary sector money advice services, and believes that the Scottish Executive should make representations to protect the interests and incomes of the vulnerable in Scotland. Supported by: Roseanna Cunningham*

S2M-1916# Brian Adam: Cuts in Local Benefits Services—That the Parliament expresses great concern about the impact of the proposed cuts by the Department of Work and Pensions in local provision of benefits advice; regrets the likely reduction in benefits uptake by many vulnerable people; deplores the unfair geographical spread of the cuts, leaving Grampian, Tayside and Fife without any local offices; recognises the consequential increased workload that will fall on local authority and voluntary sector money advice services, and believes that the Scottish Executive should make representations to protect the interests and incomes of the vulnerable in Scotland. Supported by: Roseanna Cunningham, Stewart Stevenson*

S2M-1916# Cuts in Local Benefits Services (lodged on 28 October 2004) Tricia Marwick*, Mr Kenny MacAskill*, Alex Neil*, Richard Lochhead*, Bruce Crawford*, Rob Gibson*, Eleanor Scott*, Ms Rosemary Byrne*, Carolyn Leckie*

S2M-1916# Brian Adam: Cuts in Local Benefits Services—That the Parliament expresses great concern about the impact of the proposed cuts by the Department of Work and Pensions in local provision of benefits advice; regrets the likely reduction in benefits uptake by many vulnerable people; deplores the unfair geographical spread of the cuts, leaving Grampian, Tayside and Fife without any local offices; recognises the consequential increased workload that will fall on local authority and voluntary sector money advice services, and believes that the Scottish Executive should make representations to protect the interests and incomes of the vulnerable in Scotland. Supported by: Roseanna Cunningham, Stewart Stevenson, Tricia Marwick, Mr Kenny MacAskill, Alex Neil, Richard Lochhead, Bruce Crawford, Rob Gibson, Eleanor Scott, Ms Rosemary Byrne, Carolyn Leckie, Mr Adam Ingram, Michael Matheson, Ms Sandra White, Dr Jean Turner, Donald Gorrie, John Swinburne, Jim Mather, Mrs Margaret Ewing, Linda Fabiani, Margo MacDonald, Shiona Baird, Nora Radcliffe, Frances Curran, Rosie Kane, Christine Grahame*, Mr Bruce McFee*, Robin Harper*, Fiona Hyslop*, Mr Mark Ruskell*, Tommy Sheridan*, Mike Pringle*
S2M-1916# Cuts in Local Benefits Services (lodged on 28 October 2004) Mr Jamie Stone*, Chris Ballance* Contents An A B C D E F G H I J
